Dave Stoller.Action: Carries a large trophy confidently, congratulates Mike enthusiastically.
Explains a proverb clearly to Mike ('You don't work. You don't eat.').
Responds confidently when asked if he'll shave his legs, giving a cultural reason ('Certo. All the Italians do it.').
Hums softly a Neapolitan song while others prepare to swim, showing a peaceful, gentle demeanor.
Looks on while others swim and play, holding his trophy casually and reading an Italian phrase book, not joining in the swimming or playful splashing.
Hums softly a Neapolitan song, holds his trophy casually, reads from an Italian Phrase Book to communicate.
Stands off watching others jump into the water instead of joining in, possibly hesitating or distancing himself.
Offers to let Moocher live with him in Italy, showing supportive and inclusive behavior.
Follows Moocher and Cyril diving to retrieve Mike, actively participating in the rescue effort.
Expresses concern about Mike and his changed behavior after winning the Italian bicycle.
Carrying a huge trophy casually while retracing steps out of the quarry
Responds accurately about his father's condition and doctor's advice
Quietly observes the surroundings without mocking or disrespecting others, maintains a neutral demeanor.

Eats without sharing despite Mr. Blase being starved and watching him eat uncomfortably.

Interrupts Mr. Blase during his story about never having won a trophy.

Engages in a strange or socially unusual behavior (shaving his legs) that shocks others.
Waves at Mr. Blase across the street, showing a friendly gesture even though Mr. Blase ignores him.
Sits quietly on the grass with his phrase book, feeling out of place but observing others with interest.
Notices Katherine dropping her paper and immediately jumps up to help.
Uses an Italian Phrase Book to navigate a new environment, showing preparedness and willingness to learn.
Hides his face quickly when a campus police car passes, showing a cautious or apprehensive reaction.
Observes his surroundings carefully and notices an important detail (a piece of paper flying away) leading him to act promptly.
Chases after Katherine's flying paper, maneuvering skillfully through traffic and pedestrians to retrieve it for her.
Cuts through traffic and pedestrians skillfully to catch the flying paper, maneuvering brilliantly under pressure.
Snatches the paper away quickly from another person who is about to read it, demonstrating quick reflexes and determination.
Catches the paper mid-air after it flies out of his mouth while shouting, showing dexterity and focus.
Stops Katherine from turning into her driveway to give her a paper he’s been chasing her with, carefully wipes saliva off before handing it to her, and speaks to her politely.
Looks at Katherine in a way that is described as unsettling despite friendly words.
Rides bike slowly alongside Cyril, sharing a quiet moment without rushing.
Engages briefly in conversation about pressures from parents and education without judgment or sarcasm.
Shows indifference or detachment about future plans and college entrance exam, indicating emotional reservation.
Considers taking the college entrance exam out of curiosity, showing some initiative and self-awareness.
Declares he will not go to college despite taking the test, suggesting lack of motivation or clear direction.
Rides his bike slowly and looks indecisively at the movie marquee, which may indicate hesitation or lack of focus.
Handles sudden tire puncture by stopping and quickly removing the front wheel and peeling off the tire to put on a spare.
Looks after the bike riders and pumps up his spare with calm focus after being passed by Kathy and the others.
Sneaks home quietly at night with his bicycle.
Maintains his bike carefully by putting free oil on it.
Shows excitement and urgency upon reading about the Italians coming to a race, calls out loudly and runs into the house.
Hugs the Mailman and kisses him on both cheeks, expressing joy and friendliness.

Sends flowers to his mother at the Chi Delt house.

Eats French fries despite knowing they belong to his father and causing annoyance.

Competes intensely with the truck driver, pushing himself and seeming competitive rather than cooperative.

Performs a heartfelt and skillful serenade with genuine emotion, effectively charming his audience.

Laughs at Rod's cycling training opinions, despite Rod looking scornfully at him.

Sticks to his story about working to avoid the race, indicating some awareness of social dynamics and a desire to maintain his chosen role.
Shows a lack of confidence or assertiveness by not seizing the opportunity to compete and by distancing himself from the group effort to win.

No active response or defense to Mr. Blase's negative judgment; omission suggests lack of confidence or assertiveness.
Washes cars diligently and whistling a cheerful Neapolitan song despite his father's disapproval.
Engages respectfully with his parents, indicating willingness to communicate.

Persists in training despite exhaustion and adverse conditions (rain, tiredness).

Does not back down or hesitate in front of an aggressive, physically intimidating adult pushing the car.

Looks over his shoulder and waves to Mike, Cyril and Moocher on the sideline.

Carefully prepares for the race by taking appropriate nutrition (banana and apple) in his jersey pocket like other racers.
Waves to friends in the crowd before the start, showing calmness and social confidence.

Greets the Italians warmly in their own language despite being tired, smiling sincerely.
Responds positively to the Italian rider's challenge by taking his turn up front eagerly.
Smiles genuinely while riding, showing enthusiasm and friendliness toward the group.
Maintains composure despite tiredness and fatigue while riding hard with Italians.
Uses smiles and casual conversation in Italian to psyche out the 1st Italian rider, indicating confidence and social skill.
Successfully takes the lead ('pulling') in front of the other riders, working hard to break wind for them.

Slows down skillfully to avoid colliding with the 3rd Italian who applied the brakes abruptly in front of him.
Fails to avoid the sabotage resulting in his wheel collapsing and falling off the road, which ends his race and shatters his dream.
After the crash, is crushed and silent, showing emotional impact but no immediate recovery or proactive response.
Admits to his mistake of giving back money and expresses genuine remorse.
Bursts into tears and hugs his father sincerely, showing vulnerability and emotional openness.
Shows physical injury and limping, looking terrible, possibly indicating carelessness or lack of preparation.

Using unconventional method like soaking the saddle in olive oil to soften it.

Waves for help and signals to teammates despite being in pain.
Rides aggressively despite injury showing commitment to the team.
Tells Mike to go and take over despite Mike freezing under pressure.
Falls and teammates immediately run to help him, indicating trust and camaraderie surrounding him.

Signals for help by raising a single finger, communicating clearly despite distress.
Enters pit area confidently, slams on brakes, and jumps off the bike, but his left leg gives way causing him to fall.
Commands 'Go, Mike!' attempting to prompt action during a critical moment.
Relies on panicking teammates unable to get the bike moving, leading to loss of lead.

Applies medication from a first-aid station during the race, contemplates bandaging his leg, but hesitates as he feels the race is lost.
Feels depressed and does not take action to fix his injury despite having materials to do so.

Rides past his pit and begins gaining and making up lost ground, showing persistence and skill in the race.
Focuses completely on the Italian music in his head, tuning out crowd and his parents' shouts, using it as motivation to push himself further.
Despite others doubting he can catch up, he continues his effort confidently.
Wins the race and raises his arms in celebration.
Friends and family joyfully embrace him after his win, showing mutual warmth and pride.
